Runs away from the police and sprints across a busy, two-lane street without looking, resulting in being hit by a taxi and causing a chaotic pile-up.
Pops back up after being hit by the taxi despite pain, showing physical resilience.
Successfully blends into a crowd of protesters wearing Joker masks to evade police detection.
Quickly navigates through a crowded train and uses the environment (train doors closing) to escape pursuers.
Limping and sweating but continues to move swiftly despite physical pain.
Throws a punch at a drunk guy who is aggressive towards him.
Steps out of the way instead of engaging violently when the drunk guy attacks.
Just stands in the middle of the chaotic fight without intervening or helping anyone.
Walks away calmly from the chaos and the riot started after the police shoot a protestor.
Steps out of the way when attacked, avoids confrontation skillfully.
Slips the clown mask over his face and stands calmly amidst the chaos, appearing at ease and unflustered.
Walks away calmly from a violent riot he is involved in, showing composure and control.
Taking off the mask and dropping it at his side as he steps off the train, disappearing onto the crowded platform calmly after a violent riot starts.
Effusively shakes Murray's hand and expresses genuine gratitude for the opportunity to be on the show, mentions his mother never missed the show.
Cleans himself up considerably, carefully reapplies his makeup and hair before going on stage.
Gets up to shake Murray Franklin's hand confidently despite tension in room.
Shows effusive gratitude and expresses long-time admiration towards Murray Franklin, establishing positive rapport.
Smiles back at Murray after being accepted for the show, thanks him sincerely.
Does not respond with any empathy or concern regarding news of violence and protests, appears detached and almost amused internally.
Decides to use a provocative, timely, and edgy look for his act despite the ongoing serious news events; convinces Murray to put him on the show.
Does not react appropriately to the mention of violent protests and a child's death on the subway, almost laughs, and admits he had not heard the news.
Requests to be introduced as 'The Joker,' indicating a desire for a new identity and connection to the show.
Smiles ambiguously when saying he doesn't know his real name, showing vulnerability but uncertain if sincere.
Adjusts the waist of his pants under his jacket and takes a deep breath before appearing on stage.
Quietly watches Murray through the slim gap at the end of the curtain during applause and the show.
Tries to go on stage despite visible nervousness and awkwardness, attempts to shake hands and hug others sincerely, showing effort to connect.
Fails to respond to Murray's criticism and is distracted by the spotlight, showing disengagement from social feedback.
Laughs in a way that can be interpreted as unsettling rather than friendly or warm, causing awkwardness.

Pauses and hesitates before going on stage, gets tangled in the curtain, trips over the riser, acts awkwardly including a failed handshake and hug, and appears uneasy and distracted during the interview.
Despite discomfort and mistakes, he manages to get on stage and respond to the host by starting to laugh confidently, signaling a possible embrace of his persona.
Keeps laughing and embraces his clown persona in front of the audience despite awkwardness.
Tries to make people laugh, showing intention to bring joy.
Reaches into jacket and pulls out joke book, attempting to engage the audience sincerely.
Gives in to the awkward situation by laughing along with the audience, shows some resilience by engaging with the moment rather than shutting down.
Leads an unconvincing and awkward interview, fails to clearly communicate or engage the audience effectively.
Carries a worn notebook of jokes, attempts to recover the interview by finding and telling a joke.
Wants to get the joke right by reading it carefully.
Tells a dark, morbid joke about a police officer informing a mother that her son was killed by a drunk driver.
Whispers backstage to Murray Franklin, seemingly directing or provoking the interaction.
Carefully reads and rehearses the joke to get it right on live TV.
Interrupts the host to whisper a line that changes the tone, showing awareness of control over the interaction.
Uses dark humor effectively, eliciting laughter and influencing audience reaction.
Uses dark, personal trauma as part of his comedy act, telling the audience about being sexually assaulted by mother's boyfriend and killing three men.
Continues with uncomfortable, shocking statements despite others' negative reactions and disapproval.
Continues his provocative and dark monologue on live TV despite visible discomfort and disapproval from the host and audience.
Fails to effectively read the room or adapt his behavior to the social context, causing confusion and irritation.
Maintains control of his speech and composure while delivering unsettling revelations, showing a certain confidence in his delivery.
Confesses to killing the Wall Street Three on live TV, showing no remorse.
States he has nothing left to lose and accepts his fate, indicating a detachment from society and others.
Acknowledges the cruelty and lack of civility in society, expresses frustration that people don't consider others' perspectives.
Mocks and disparages the victims of his violence by insulting their singing ability.
Questions and challenges societal norms and figures like Thomas Wayne, showing a critical but possibly resentful viewpoint.
Engages Murray Franklin in a careful, meaningful interview, speaking thoughtfully and with some command over the conversation.
Demonstrates self-awareness by acknowledging he does not fit the image of a movement leader, yet uses his platform to express a larger social commentary.
Fails to control the crowd's perception, as seen by the audience's audible groans in response to his joke, indicating a misread of social cues.
Effectively uses personal grievances as a rhetorical strategy to challenge societal elites like Thomas Wayne, showing strategic intelligence.
Raises his voice and appears emotionally overwhelmed during the interview, which could undermine his credibility and perceived competence.
Howls at the moon, openly declares his rebellion against societal expectations.
Accuses Murray Franklin of being awful and mocking him on live TV, confrontational and resentful.
Confronts Murray Franklin directly on live TV, delivers a pointed and calculated rebuke, controlling the narrative and commanding attention.
Commits murder live on TV, provoking widespread riots and violence, showing disregard for consequences and impulsive behavior.
Pulls a gun on Murray Franklin and shoots him on live TV, causing terror and bloodshed.
Pulls Randall's gun on live TV and shoots Murray Franklin in the head, causing chaos on the set and terrorizing the audience.
Plans and executes a highly risky and violent act on live television, demonstrating boldness and the ability to manipulate a situation to get attention.
Fails to effectively control the aftermath of his violent act, immediately tackled by security guards and stagehands, losing physical control over the situation.
Bangs his head repeatedly against the steel mesh cage in frustration and pain during police transport.
Bangs his head repeatedly against the steel mesh cage in the police car
Remains handcuffed and passive while the police officers taunt him during transit
Observes the chaos outside the police car, reflected in the window, but does not intervene
Falls out of the flipped squad car, handcuffed, bloody and broken, shows signs of physical vulnerability and no attempt to escape.
Pauses with jagged glass in hand, appearing about to cut his wrists while aware of approaching sirens, indicating indecision and lack of immediate problem-solving.
Laughs uncontrollably, enjoys a joke only he understands, refuses to share it.
Engages with hospital doctor quietly, responds politely to questions.
Keeps personal thoughts private, indicating emotional distance.
Stops laughing on command, answers some questions with simple nods and short statements, acknowledges medication is working.
Laughs uncontrollably to the point of tears, struggles to communicate clearly, has a glazed and medicated appearance, stitched smile indicating physical alteration for forced expression.
Slides his blank journal to the doctor, then smiles as she discovers it's empty.
Dances happily down the hospital hallway, engaging with imaginary music despite his situation.
Slides his journal to the doctor but it is completely blank, deceiving the doctor.
Smiles knowingly when the doctor is confused by the blank journal, showing some awareness and control over the situation.
Dances confidently down the hallway at Arkham, executing slide steps and spins, indicating a moment of skillful physical expression and self-assurance.
